# []{#cb1.xhtml_pxxi .pagebreak aria-label="xxi" role="doc-pagebreak"}About the Authors {#cb1.xhtml_cb1 .fmtitle1}

<figure id="fig0_1a" class="contrib-image">
<img src="D:\OsMEN\content\ebooks\drm_free\media/images/fig0_1.jpg" role="presentation" />
</figure>

**Tom Skovholt** is professor emeritus at the University of Minnesota and a Licensed Psychologist in counseling practice and consulting. He has extensive experience as a professor, counselor, and therapist.

He has written and taught for many years about core issues in the helping professions. *The Resilient Practitioner* has been described, along with books by Victor Frankel and Carl Rogers, as one of the three most important books for beginning counselors. In the larger area of professional development, Skovholt and colleague Helge Rønnestad have been described as "The inventors of the study of counselor/therapist development." Tom has received professional awards for research, teaching, and contributions to professional psychology as well as being a Fulbright professor in Turkey and a counseling professor in Singapore. He has offered many workshops on practitioner resiliency. Tom is the author or co-author of 14 books. He believed that professional counseling is one of the great inventions of the last half of the 20th century, and he is enthusiastic about the level of valuable work done by practitioners everywhere! One focus of his professional work is to "help the helper" as a way to leverage the valuable work of all the relationship-intense professions such as counseling, therapy, teaching, nursing, medicine, other health professions, ministry, academic advising, and other fields.

<figure id="fig0_1b" class="contrib-image1">
<img src="D:\OsMEN\content\ebooks\drm_free\media/images/fig0_2.jpg" role="presentation" />
</figure>

**Michelle Trotter-Mathison, PhD,** is a licensed psychologist in private practice in St. Paul, Minnesota. Michelle is committed to helping people increase resilience through self-compassion, mindfulness, and shame resilience. She is trained as a certified Daring Way™ facilitator through Dr. Brené Brown\'s organization and facilitates the Daring Way™ []{#cb1.xhtml_pxxii .pagebreak aria-label="xxii" role="doc-pagebreak"}in group and individual formats. Michelle is dedicated to practitioner resiliency and enjoys working with practitioners in the relationship-intense professions and speaking on the topic. Michelle is a co-editor of *Voices from the Field: Defining Moments in Counselor and Therapist Development*.
:::

::: {.section .preface role="doc-preface"}
# []{#preface1.xhtml_pxxix .pagebreak aria-label="xxix" role="doc-pagebreak"}Preface {#preface1.xhtml_preface1 .fmtitle1}

How does the opera singer take care of the voice?

> The baseball pitcher, the arm?
>
> The woodcutter, the axe?
>
> The photographer, the eyes?
>
> The ballerina, the legs and feet?
>
> The practitioner (in a helping, caring, relationship-intense professions), the self?

In this book, we address the intense giving of oneself to enhance the lives of others. It is the importance of the intense giving, and the fragility of it, that has been the central focus of this book in its first edition in 2000, 2nd edition in 2010, the 3rd edition in 2016 and now the 4th edition. We have spent many months rewriting the book for this fourth edition. There is a new chapter Characteristics of Highly Resilient Practitioners: The Resilient Practitioner Compass and existing chapters have been rewritten and updated with the latest research. For us, Tom and Michelle, it has been a very engaging, difficult and highly meaningful project. We have been so encouraged by the response we have received from readers of this book and those in our workshops.

We have written this book for people in a broad group of career fields: the helping professions, education, health occupations, and the clergy. Some readers may not identify with this broad occupational group (counselors, therapists, teachers, professors, social workers, clergy, nurses, doctors, physical therapists, other health professionals and more) because they seem so different. For example, a public school teacher may think that her work is very different from that of a nurse or a counselor. Yes, there are differences. Novices in training are often taught about the differences and uniqueness of their own field. We know these can be important for career identity and unique role and function. On the other hand, our own experience in counseling, education, and health services has helped us to see that there are great commonalities among counseling, teaching, and healing. We feel that there are many work concerns that are shared among these professional groups. We view all of these as caring professions because of common work ingredients.[]{#preface1.xhtml_pxxx .pagebreak aria-label="xxx" role="doc-pagebreak"}

A leading career development inventory, the Campbell Interest and Skill Survey, combines "helping others through teaching, healing and counseling" into one of seven work orientations (Campbell, 1994, p. 2), providing evidence for similarity among these fields. When reading this material, we invite you to consider the commonalities rather than the differences in the careers. If the commonalities can be understood, then this material may be of use to a variety of individuals working in different caring professions.

The questions to be asked by all are: how do those in the helping-caring, relationship-intense professions, who use their own self as a method of change, prevent burnout and maintain professional vitality? How does one establish balance between other-care and self-care? What are the keys to practitioner resiliency? In this book, we ask these questions and hope to provide the reader with useful ways to address these questions and find valuable answers.
:::

:::: section
# []{#fm-chapter1.xhtml_pxxxi .pagebreak aria-label="xxxi" role="doc-pagebreak"}Skovholt Practitioner Professional Resiliency and Self-Care Inventory {#fm-chapter1.xhtml_fm-chapter1 .fmtitle1}

::: section
## 2014 Version {#fm-chapter1.xhtml_secfm1 .head1}

The purpose of the inventory is to provide self-reflection for practitioners and students in the helping, health, and caring professions, broadly defined. All of these fields are relationship-intense fields in which the welfare of the Other (client, patient, student, advisee, mentee, etc.) is primary. *Practitioner* here refers to individuals in these professions. All of these professions are distinct, with specialized areas of knowledge and techniques. However, they are united by the enormous amount of emotional investment needed for the I-Thou relationship with the Other, who is often experiencing suffering or human need of one kind or another.

Questions are addressed to both active practitioners and also students in training programs across a broad range of the caring/relationship-intense professions. Some of the questions are more relevant to some professionals or students in some training programs than others.

[]{#fm-chapter1.xhtml_pxxxii .pagebreak aria-label="xxxii" role="doc-pagebreak"}Copyright © 2010 Thomas M. Skovholt and 2014 Revised

**The checklist consists of four sub-scales: Professional Vitality, Personal Vitality, Professional Stress, and Personal Stress.**

**1** = Strongly Disagree, **2** = Disagree, **3** = Undecided, **4** = Agree, **5** = Strongly Agree

# []{#chapter1.xhtml_p3 .pagebreak aria-label="3" role="doc-pagebreak"}[Chapter 1]{.chapnum}[Boundaried Generosity as Key: Caring for Others vs. Self-Care]{.chaptitle} {#chapter1.xhtml_chapter1 .chaplabel}

Thomas M. Skovholt and Michelle Trotter-Mathison

DOI: [10.4324/9781003221388-2](https://doi.org/10.4324/9781003221388-2){aria-label="D.O.I. link to this document."}
:::

Practitioners in the helping professions have a baked-in dilemma: caring for self vs. caring for others. Caring for self is the biological imperative; caring for others is the occupational calling. The pull of these poles is an occupation reality and difficult to resolve because of the caring nature of helpers, healers, and educators.

Based on our own extensive research with expert practitioners, we have developed a construct Boundaried Generosity as a way out of this professional dilemma. The 15 chapters of this fourth edition are filled with multiple ways we illuminate this dilemma and offer Boundary Generosity and other solutions for the helping practitioner on the way to professional resilience.

Here we go on the wild ride of the helping professions. Exhausted when saying yes, guilty when saying no -- this tension is between giving and taking, between other-care and self-care. This is a universal dilemma in the human drama. It is just more intense for those who are, by nature and inclination, emotionally attuned to the needs of others. It gets highly illuminated when intense human interaction -- therapy, counseling, healing, teaching, guiding, advising, ministry, or helping -- is the occupational core. Here, giving of oneself is the constant requirement for success. Caring for others is the precious commodity. It is caring for the Other[^1^](#chapter1.xhtml_en1_1){#chapter1.xhtml_en1_11b .noteref role="doc-noteref"} person when by nature we are, as a species, geared to meet the needs of the self, which provides much of the strength for these caring, relationship-intense professions.

The best ones who enter these helping fields have this natural lean toward the needs of others. They see, feel, smell, touch, and hear human need all around them and want to respond.

The best ones struggle the most and figure it out; or leave; or burn, from the inside to the outside, while hope dies. It is not natural to put the Other person before the self. The human senses -- smell, sight, taste, touch, hearing -- are there to protect the me, to promote the me. To know the world through the senses of the Other is like swimming upstream, hard to do and easy to resist. How much should one work for the Other -- this moment, this hour, this day, this week, this month, this year, this decade, this career? How much to give this hour to the one I am trying []{#chapter1.xhtml_p4 .pagebreak aria-label="4" role="doc-pagebreak"}to help when there will be another day of many hours, and another week of many more hours, and another month of even more hours? How much to give of the self for the Other this hour? This is a constant question for those in this big group of practitioners with these different names: the Caring Professions, the Relationship-Intense Professions, the Helping Professions, Health-Education-Human Development fields. To see human suffering and need all around oneself and to constantly be on the teeter-totter of other-care vs. self-care -- do I give or pull back -- demand its own kind of resilience. Hence, this book is written.

Brené [Brown (2017)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_49){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_49 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} inspired many practitioners when she said: "People are Hard to Hate Close Up. Move In. Speak Truth to Bullshit. Be Civil. Hold Hands, With Strangers. Strong Back. Soft Front. Wild Heart" (p. 36). For the practitioner with a wild heart that is also an open heart, human distress is seen, heard and felt in all directions. This human distress is expressed so well in art, poetry, writing, and music. It is there in The Scream, an 1893 painting by Edward Munch, in Van Gogh\'s intense colors, in Amanda Gordon\'s poetry, in the writings of Brené Brown on human vulnerability, in Billie Eilish songs, with the Beatles' "A Hard Day\'s Night," Paul Simon\'s "Fifty Ways to Leave Your Lover," Faron Young "Hello Walls," and song after song.

Practitioners are internally tuned to feel anguish when seeing memorials, museum, and places of human pain: looking at the names at the Vietnam Memorial, driving across the Golden Gate bridge and thinking not of the beautiful view as much as the number of people who have jumped, seeing the highway sign in Kuwait for the road to Basra and thinking of the firebombing of the retreating Iraq soldiers and Kuwait citizens in those vehicles, walking up the hills at Normandy and seeing the hundreds of crosses in the cemetery, standing in Seoul and imagining the fighting there between Koreans and Koreans in 1050, walking along new Israel Army recruits, and wondering about their feelings, while going through Yad Vashem, the World Holocaust Remembrance Center in Jerusalem, going by a hospital and imaging, during the Covid days, the ICU and the suffering patients, the depleted-despairing-exhausted staff of nurses, respiration therapists, and physicians and then the vivid images from the war in Ukraine.

As we have said, the term practitioner is our umbrella term for those in relationship-intense fields such as therapists, counselors, social workers, teachers, professors, nurses, physicians, other health care providers, clergy, family law attorneys, and more. All focus on the other\'s *Hot Center*, a visual metaphor of the place where a person holds their most precious -- important -- salient realities about their own life. One of the great gifts to the human family by those in the caring fields is to attend to the Other\'s Hot Center and absorb, like a sponge, negative emotions of the Other: anxiety, depression, anger, despair, discouragement, fear, hopelessness, and more. For the practitioner, there is bearing witness: seeing need, []{#chapter1.xhtml_p5 .pagebreak aria-label="5" role="doc-pagebreak"}feeling need, hearing the emotions of suffering ... confusion ... loneliness ... being broken ... anxious ... depressed ... angry. And so much more.

How does the practitioner do it without being captured by a "sadness of the soul?" How does one avoid not only ordinary burnout but also extraordinary burnout? How does one not develop vicarious traumatization and lose optimism? How does one not lose the hope that Jane Goodell, the chimpanzee researcher, speaks about as she crisscrosses the planet urging action against environmental degradation.

This book is about this great dilemma. How to have an open heart without being trapped in the quicksand of human despair? Not once but over many years of work as a practitioner. In this book, we are excited to present strategies and tips that we have curated over many years of working as practitioners, researching resilient practitioner strategies, and presenting ideas to audiences of psychologists, physicians, social workers, teachers, professors, academic advisors, and others in the United States and many countries. These audiences have helped us sense the urgency behind the need for burnout prevention and to refine strategies and tips.

Next, we will offer a tip and a central question for the resilient practitioner.

::: section
## Tip: Becoming a Guide for Your Own Boundaried Generosity {#chapter1.xhtml_sec1_1 .head1}

The term Boundaried Generosity evolved out of our research interviews with ten master therapists. After these multiple interviews with these individuals, we developed a Portrait of the Master Therapist ([Skovholt et al., 2004](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_365){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_365 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}). One Characteristic that emerged was *Piloted by Boundaried Generosity.* Boundaried is a version of the well-known term boundaries: learn how to have them, practice them, use them in one\'s life. Writing a few words about boundaries does not describe the complexity of how to use them. The second word is Generosity. It means giving of oneself, being kind, being unselfish. We are often told by religious leaders and fund raisers to be generous! Here, in this book we are focusing on the practitioner\'s generosity toward the emotional and interpersonal needs of the Other person. Boundaried Generosity can be expressed in so many ways depending on the situation. Sometimes a practitioner expresses a lot of generosity; other times there is a need for a boundaried reaction. The Boundaried Generosity dance. For example, a new graduate counseling student in practicum may offer to extend her emotional energy to the few clients she has. The Boundaried part may be small and the Generosity large. Years later with three small children at home and multiple students, clients, and clinical supervisees at work the Boundaried part may have expanded, and the generosity part may be expressed in smaller doses. Try this -- put your hands in front of you and move them vertical []{#chapter1.xhtml_p6 .pagebreak aria-label="6" role="doc-pagebreak"}and then horizonal and imagine how your Boundaries Generosity can expand and contract. A resilient practitioner learns, often through painful, exhausting experience, how to be a Connoisseur of their own Boundaried Generosity dance.
:::

::: section
## Key Question: Who Is Responsible for Building the Resilience and Burnout Prevention Greenhouse -- The Practitioner, the Organization, or Both? {#chapter1.xhtml_sec1_2 .head1}

This question is at the heart of much debate in the field; the practitioner says to the organization: "It is your job to create a thriving environment for hard working practitioners!" This is the stance of [Maslach and Leiter (1997)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_233){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_233 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} in *The Truth About Burnout.* They say it is the responsibility of the organization. [Broome et al. (2009)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_47){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_47 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} advocate for positive leadership for the staff in a drug treatment program. Conversely, the organization says to the practitioner: "You create your own thriving practitioner self!" And that is the focus of most of the writing on burnout prevention. *180 Days of Self-Care for Busy Educators* ([Boogren, 2019](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_33){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_33 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}) is an example of this.

When the organization creates a greenhouse for the practitioner and the practitioner also creates their own greenhouse, the environment can be a happy, vibrant place. And one would predict many positive client outcomes. When neither the organization nor the practitioner creates a greenhouse, the reality is a greenhouse without water, sunlight, or soil. The practitioner is diminished and there are fewer positive client outcomes.

It is not easy to care for oneself for those naturally attuned to the needs of the suffering Other. Carl Rogers is considered a founder of the profession of counseling with his, not so revolutionary ideas anymore: sit facing each other, focus on feelings as an empathy expert, put the helping relationship in the spotlight with an emphasis on the client\'s ability to grow and reduce the focus on psychopathology. However, as one of the founders of the modern profession of counseling, Carl Rogers was a work in progress, struggling with the same things that many of us do.

> I have always been better at caring for and looking after others than I have been at caring for myself. But in these later years, I have made progress.
>
> Carl Rogers at age 75 ([Rogers, 1995](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_325){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_325 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}, p. 80)

The giving of oneself; one\'s heart, soul, energy, attention, empathy, intellect, and more makes for the power of the helping professions. The following three authors describe aspects of this intense giving. Famous novelist Steven King said: "Teaching school is like having jumper cables hooked to your brain, draining all the juice out of you" (Cited by [Grothe, 2008](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_147){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_147 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}, p. 15). And famous therapy writer [Yalom (2002)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_434){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_434 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}: "Too often, we therapists neglect our personal relationships. Our work becomes our life. []{#chapter1.xhtml_p7 .pagebreak aria-label="7" role="doc-pagebreak"}At the end of our workday, having given so much of ourselves, we feel drained of desire for more relationship" (p .252). In her beautifully written, and international bestselling book: *The Language of Kindness: A Nurse\'s Story* ([Watson, 2018](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_415){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_415 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}, p. 282), she wrote: "The nurse repeatedly shallows a fragment of the trauma ... And taking in even a small dose of tragedy and grief, and loneliness and sadness, daily over a career is dangerous and it is exhausting."

A teacher speaking for many others:

> I tend to give my time away to others before I take it for myself.
>
> Junior high school teacher, 1996
:::

::: {.section .introduction role="doc-introduction"}
## A Short Introduction to Resilience {#chapter1.xhtml_sec1_3 .head1}

*Resilience*, a word that is being used more and more during recent years, refers to a person\'s ability to adapt in a positive way to difficult and trying situations. [Park et al. (2021)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_293){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_293 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} examined psychological resilience during the COVID-19 pandemic with their detailed article in the journal, *American Psychologist*. [Luthar et al. (2000)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_220){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_220 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} have written a scholarly review of the topic, one with 169 references! Or, as a short cut, you can just think of the term *resilience* in this way: the capacity to bounce back from a negative force -- like a fishing bobber, pushed under water, pops back up.

Laura [Hillenbrand (2010)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_168){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_168 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} describes Louie Zamperini, an American in the military who became a POW, this way in her bestseller book *Unbroken: A World War II Story of Survival, Resilience, and Redemption.* It is a story of a man who went through enormous suffering and pain, described in page after page of this book, and kept coming back. In the first page of the preface, we read of 1943. Louie was in the Pacific Ocean, where he "... lay across a small raft drifting westward ... The men had been adrift for twenty-seven days ... deep into Japanese controlled waters" (p. xvii). Louie was captured and spent many months in concentration camps where he was the special victim of a brutal guard ... but, like the resilient bobber, he kept physically and emotionally bouncing back in the camp, and in the decades after, too. Then in 1998, 55 years later, he returned to the site of a concentration camp where he had been held in a cage decades before. Now in triumph, 81-year-old Louie carried the Olympic torch while the local people watched in respect as they saw "the old and joyful man, running" (p. 398). The title *Unbroken* captures the life story of Louie Zamperini so well. Resilience and more resilience in action.

So many heroic stories of altruism reveal examples of balancing of other-care and self-care: Rosa Parks on the bus comes to mind, as do the Protestant reformer Martin Luther, social worker Jane Addams at Hull House in Chicago, Captain Chesley Sullenberger landing his plane on the Hudson and checking to see again and again that all were out as the plane []{#chapter1.xhtml_p8 .pagebreak aria-label="8" role="doc-pagebreak"}filled with water. Working as a Japanese civil servant in Lithuania in 1940, without asking for authorization, Chiune Sugihara spent 20 hours a day filling out exit visas for desperate Jews ([Levine, 1996](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_211){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_211 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}). In the teeter-totter of other-care vs. self-care, he swung to other-care because, he said, it was the right thing to do.

The resilience demanded of the helping professional is of another dimension; there is not the intensity where basic physical survival is the axis that one\'s life revolves around. Yet, the helping professional often expresses the agonizing pull between other-care and self-care: there is a continual pull, constant strain, a tautness. It may not be intense. The common form is subtle, felt as body tension. Usually, it does not knock one over. It is more like a small wave rippling through -- a wave going in two directions or waves pulling in three directions. Or is it four? Sometimes it is a skirmish that quickly becomes war.

To be successful in the helping professions, we must continually maintain professional vitality and avoid depleted caring. For counselors, therapists, teachers, clergy, and health professionals, this can be a very difficult task. Since [Freudenberger (1974)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_126){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_126 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} first used the term *burnout*, many authors have discussed the difficulty of professional vitality in the helping and related fields ([Baker, 2003](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_14){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_14 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}; [Boogren, 2019](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_33){.biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}; [Canfield, 2005](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_53){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_53 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}; [Carter & Barnett, 2014](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_57){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_57 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}; [Corey et al., 2018](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_76){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_76 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}; [Larson, 1993](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_209){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_209 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}; [Linley & Joseph, 2007](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_216){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_216 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}; [Maslach, 1982](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_230){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_230 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}; [Mathieu, 2012](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_238){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_238 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}; Norcross & VandenBos, 2018; [Papastylianou et al., 2009](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_292){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_292 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}; [Robinson, 1992](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_321){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_321 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}; [Rothschild & Rand, 2006](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_336){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_336 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}; [Shirom et al., 2009](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_351){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_351 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}; [Sussman, 1995](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_394){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_394 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}; [van Dernoot Lipsky & Burk, 2009](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_410){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_410 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}).

A central occupational strength in the caring professions -- perspective taking -- makes the boundary regulation between the needs of others and the needs of self a difficult task. Occupationally, we are trained to see life from the perspective of the Other, and we do this naturally by personality, as well. L. King (personal communication, February 1996) suggests that we often have a personal history of active caring for others: "We are often the great friend who listens, the 'fixer' in a relationship, the diplomatic person in a disagreement, and/or the 'helper' within the family of origin." In another place, Tom ([Skovholt, 1988](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_356){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_356 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}) wrote:

> One of the most distinguished characteristics of our profession is our intense focusing on highly skilled perspective taking: a combination of empathy, perceptual flexibility, tolerance for ambiguity and affective sensitivity. When successful, all of this translates into a profound ability to understand the world as other people understand it. This well-honed ability, one of our occupational strengths, is not possessed by many people in other occupations. (p. 283)

In the theater of life, the Other person becomes the illuminated part of the stage; our I is often outside the illumination. The lives of others -- their hopes, ideas, goals, aspirations, pains, fears, despair, anger -- are []{#chapter1.xhtml_p9 .pagebreak aria-label="9" role="doc-pagebreak"}in focus. Like a leaf under a microscope, we see all of this in highly illuminated detail. As a counselor, therapist, educator, clergy member, or health practitioner, the Other gets our attention. Out of the illuminated microscope, we can easily lose sight of our own needs. We even lose sight of the need to not respond to all needs around us.

In addition to perspective taking that focuses on the needs of the Other person, we often are pulled to see things from multiple perspectives. That way we can naturally engage in activities such as family counseling in which we can see the issues from the viewpoint of each family member, for example, mother, father, daughter, and son. Some people would hear of the Wallace [Stevens (1923)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_388){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_388 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} poem, "Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird," and say, "Wow, there are thirteen ways?" Those in the helping professions often use multiple lenses at the same time to understand others.

Being able to see the world of human need through multiple viewpoints can be valuable. Sometimes, though, those in the caring professions lose touch with their own viewpoint and their own needs.

Settings of intense human need can be very unsettling for those in the helping, teaching, and caring professions. This occurs because we are taught to assess, experience, and respond to human need at a much more intense level than the public. That is the goal of training. Nursing homes are an example of a difficult arena. With a honed ability to do perspective taking, one can easily feel the loneliness, fear, and despair of the residents. One practitioner struggled mightily to visit her client in such a place without being overwhelmed by all the other human need. She was caught in the push-pull of exhaustion versus guilt while searching for boundaries of when to reach out and when to pull back. Here, the "shoemaker has no shoes" problem of low self-care can easily occur. [Sussman (1995)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_394){.biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} comments:

> Many therapists, for example, grew up playing the role of caretaker, go-between, parentified child or burden-bearer within their families of origin. Having learned at an early age to attune themselves to others, therapists often have great difficulty attending to their own emotional needs. (p. 4)

Where in the practitioner\'s life is self-preservation and self-care held and nurtured? The answer can be found in the struggle between altruism and self-preservation within the bigger human drama. As a species, we have been remarkably able to increase our numbers. In recent years, it has been at an astonishing rate, from 2.5 billion in 1950 to 8 billion in 2022. We have accomplished this growth and domination of all other living species with an acute sense of species self-preservation.

Biologically, each of us is wired to preserve the self. The senses continually warn us of danger. The physical defense system fights disease and []{#chapter1.xhtml_p10 .pagebreak aria-label="10" role="doc-pagebreak"}threat with white blood cells, energy pouring from the adrenal glands, and other miraculous processes. The desire to have children is often thought of as a biological self-preservation. The psychological defenses keep us from harm using denial, rationalization, and projection.

Just as self-preservation seems to be an urgent human drive, we can also find evidence that altruism and self-sacrifice are central. In the winter of 2012 in Newtown, Connecticut, Sandy Hook Elementary School was tragically attacked by a shooter ([Associated Press, 2012](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_10){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_10 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}). While the school was under siege, teachers and administrators put the schoolchildren\'s lives ahead of their own. Several accounts of heroism were reported in the aftermath of the shooting. Teacher Victoria Soto was said to have physically shielded the children in her first-grade class. Principal Dawn Hochsprung and psychologist Mary Sherlach put themselves between their students and the shooter by attempting to intervene, rushing toward the shooter. All three died in the shooting, offering the ultimate sacrifice as they worked to do what came naturally to them as individuals and as helping professionals: to protect and care for the children they served.

Books such as *Man\'s Search for Meaning* ([Frankl, 1963](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_122){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_122 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} and *Do Unto Others: Extraordinary Acts of Ordinary People* ([Oliner, 2003](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_280){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_280 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}) tell of ordinary people who have made extraordinary sacrifices of the self. [Kohlberg (1979)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_198){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_198 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}, a leading scholar in moral development, measures morality with the famous case of Heinz, a boy caught in the dilemma of either stealing medications to keep his mother alive or not stealing -- caring for others versus self-preservation.

The dilemma of Heinz is a sample of the larger human drama of altruism versus self-care. Within this larger human stage, counselors, therapists, teachers, clergy, and health professionals do their work, attempting to live on the balance beam between too much other-care and too much self-care. For example, how much sleep deprivation should the practitioner endure to prepare to help the client, student, parishioner, or patient the next day? This is just one example of many dilemmas continually faced by practitioners in the relationship-intense fields.

Exploration of the practitioner\'s world begins in the next chapter. There, we explore the deep satisfaction of the work. We are speaking of the deep, and often subtle, pleasure that comes when enveloped by work that aims to make life better for others.
:::

::: section
## A Few Words About Hope {#chapter1.xhtml_sec1_4 .head1}

Practitioners offer the Other person, more than anything else, hope! Hope makes things possible. It is an essential ingredient for human development. Jane Goodall, world famous chimpanzee researcher, knows about hope. She went to Africa as a young uneducated woman hopeful that she could use scientific observation methods to understand chimps. []{#chapter1.xhtml_p11 .pagebreak aria-label="11" role="doc-pagebreak"}Few believed this unknown woman would make profound discoveries. But she did! Tom first read of her work while taking a graduate class "Social behavior from fish to man" at the University of Chicago. She became the first to discover, that not only humans but also chimpanzees used tools. It happened at an extraordinary moment, as she watched a chimp, she named David Greybeard use a tool to collect termites. In *The Book of Hope* ([Goodall & Abrams, 2021](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_143){#chapter1.xhtml_b1refbib_143 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}), Jane Goodell talks of the power of hope as central to the restoration of a world free from degradation. She had these simple words for us:

> We can always hope.
>
> [Goodall & Abrams (2021](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_143){.biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}, p. 222)
:::

::: section

# []{#chapter2.xhtml_p13 .pagebreak aria-label="13" role="doc-pagebreak"}[Chapter 2]{.chapnum}[Joys, Rewards, and Gifts of Practitioner Practice]{.chaptitle} {#chapter2.xhtml_chapter2 .chaplabel}

Thomas M. Skovholt and Michelle Trotter-Mathison

DOI: [10.4324/9781003221388-3](https://doi.org/10.4324/9781003221388-3){aria-label="D.O.I. link to this document."}
:::

The work can be hard, difficult, distressing, frustrating, never-ending, and isolating. Constructs describe the difficulties: burnout, compassion fatigue, emotional depletion, vicarious trauma, lack of success, sense of failure, and on and on. But the trumpets of joys, rewards, and gifts of practice are often even louder. This chapter describes the multiple satisfactions of a career in the helping professions.

Some interesting books focus on the positive emotions, something of great importance to helping practitioners who need balance away from their work focus on clients' suffering and distress. Here is one title: *Awe* ([Kelter, 2023](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_192){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_192 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}) and another: *The Good Life* ([Waldinger & Schulz, 2023](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_413){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_413 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}). How about this from George Bernard Shaw:

> This is the true joy in life, the being used for a purpose recognized by yourself as a mighty one ... the being a force of Nature instead of a feverish selfish little clod of ailments and grievances complaining that the world will not devote itself to making you happy.
>
> [Larson (1993](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_209){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_209 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}, p. 2)

Here are a few short statements that express some Joys, Rewards, and Gifts of Practitioner Practice.

> Joys
>
> Seeing the sun arise in the morning
>
> Remembering the kindness of an early mentor
>
> Connecting in time with a client/patient/student
>
> Deep life meaning of comforting a child in the night hours
>
> Wanting to sing all the way home after a good session

> Rewards
>
> The baked in reward of self-development
>
> The emotional intimacy of one-way caring
>
> Chipping away at reducing human suffering
>
> Intellectual stimulation of trying to understand people
>
> Financial benefits of the work

> []{#chapter2.xhtml_p14 .pagebreak aria-label="14" role="doc-pagebreak"}Gifts
>
> Development of wisdom with time and patience
>
> Healing the wounded healer
>
> Species immortality, going on through others
>
> Learning about human paradoxes and complexity

> Life need not be easy, provided only that it is not empty.
>
> Lisa Meitner cited by [Maggio (1997](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_223){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_223 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}, p. 12)

> In teaching others, we teach ourselves.
>
> Proverb

> A teacher affects eternity; he can never tell where his influence stops.
>
> [H. Adams (1918](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_4){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_4 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}, p. 300)

> A person who saves one life, is as if he saved a whole world.
>
> The Talmud ([Danby, 1933](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_84){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_84 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}, p. 388)

Most readers of this book are nurturers of human development. This can be highly rewarding. Making a positive difference in human life -- in the growth and health of the Other person -- is a central career interest for counselors, therapists, teachers, health professionals, clergy, and other practitioners, too. The close connection to others and the opportunity to help, teach, guide, advise, and heal people brings the joys, rewards, and gifts of practice. Being successful in helping relationships can produce a profound sense of satisfaction. Just as [Norcross and Guy (2018)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_274){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_274 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} say: "There is no greater pleasure than knowing that you made a real, lasting difference in the life of another human being. To be present at the moment of significant insight or change in the life of a client is a spiritual experience that connect the psychotherapist to the flow of life and creation ..." (p. 22)

People have asked us why not lab research or a technical field such as software design. We have a variety of answers, such as experiencing a wonderful sense of satisfaction in working with people struggling with life\'s difficulties. Interacting closely with the most complex of all species is so enriching. The opportunity to try to make human life better for others is a great privilege. And to get a salary for often deeply satisfying work adds to the privilege of having such work. What are some of the specific joys, rewards, and gifts of practice?

::: section
## Joys of Practice {#chapter2.xhtml_sec2_1 .head1}

The focus of the work is on positively affecting human need. This goal can be elusive and difficult to achieve, a reality quite familiar to veteran practitioners. Consequently, when the practitioner hits a bull\'s-eye of success, there is a joy-of-practice reaction. Witness these joy-of-practice reactions.

[]{#chapter2.xhtml_p15 .pagebreak aria-label="15" role="doc-pagebreak"}Michelle recalls a practitioner joy that drew her into the professional helping field:

> As a lay helper right out of college, I worked at a summer residential camp for adolescents who were struggling with emotional and behavioral issues. I worked with one young woman who I will call Mary. Slowly, through our work together, I was seeing small indications that Mary liked setting goals and making changes in her life. After a special outing celebrating Mary\'s birthday, she came to me and said: "I had a really fun day today. All my other birthdays I was gone -- drunk or high -- but today I had a lot of fun. Thank you, thank you for today." This early experience of helping and seeing this young woman feel cared about and start to connect to her sense of agency in her own life drew me to the caring professions. I wanted to be a part of people\'s journeys wherein they connect to themselves and their capacity for growth.

Tom recalls a practitioner joy, a bolt of appreciation that felt like the nurturing warmth of a summer sun.

> I received a phone message long after the counseling work was over. The former client said, "Thank you, Tom, for the fantastic work you did in the counseling and consulting; it was so valuable. May come back but everything is good now."

*Good*, *very good*, *excellent*, *helpful*, *feel much better, fantastic, am more hopeful* -- these are reassuring, kind, and encouraging words from clients about our work together. These words get our hearts pumping and corpuscles jumping. We are reminded of Frank McCourt, who taught adolescents for 30 years in the New York Public Schools and later wrote *Teacher Man* ([2005](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_244){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_244 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}), and his words: "Sometimes they will tell you that was a pretty good lesson and you're on top of the world. That somehow gives you energy and makes you want to sing on the way home" (p. 77).

[Larson (1993)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_209){.biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} asked nurses to describe "the most positive moment he or she ever had as a helper." Three of them said:

> When a wife of a patient whose case I just opened called the office after I left their home and told my supervisor, "Thank you for sending us such a wonderful nurse."
>
> When a patient said to me, "I'm so glad you're my nurse today because I wanted you to be the one to be with me on the day I die." She died at the end of my shift that day.
>
> A mother of a child with leukemia once said, "We come to this clinic every week and know that you care for many, many children, but when you come to see us, I feel like we are the only people you have seen that day." (pp. 6--7)

[]{#chapter2.xhtml_p16 .pagebreak aria-label="16" role="doc-pagebreak"}A senior psychologist at a Southern university described to Tom a joy in his practice:

> I had a very nice phone message when I checked in yesterday (on my birthday); a client who I worked with about four years ago had called to tell me that she is doing very well, is about to be married, and feels that the only reason she is alive and living so happily now is because of the work we did together. She had been clinically depressed and suicidal for months, and I had worked my butt off with her, such a nice result!

For a member of the clergy, the pleasure of helping came in this way:

> One day he went to visit a woman who was very ill. As he started to leave the room, the woman spoke to him: "You have been such an important person in my life. I want you to know that I have great love for you." These kind words sailed straight into the minister\'s heart.
>
> [Rupp (1994](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_339){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_339 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}, p. 17)

An elementary school teacher experienced a similar "practitioner joy":

> This past fall I received in the mail two letters from two former students, then beginning fifth grade. They were asked by their teacher to write a letter to their favorite elementary teacher. These two girls each wrote to me, telling me that I had been their favorite, and they each had their reasons why ... The letters brought tears to my eyes, and I know I will save them forever. I kept them at my desk this whole past year, as a reminder that I'm a good teacher and that I am positively influencing children\'s lives. Receiving those letters was one of the happiest moments during my teaching career.
>
> S. McNeill, personal communication (1996)

Can you think of anything better than to have a ringside seat in the human drama and, at times, assist in making the drama turn out well? We are fortunate to be in the helping professions. Practitioners acknowledge this with happy memories of past practitioner experiences, enjoyable present work, and positive anticipation of the future in this field.
:::

::: section
## Rewards of Practice {#chapter2.xhtml_sec2_2 .head1}

The relationship-intense fields can provide many "psychic income" rewards. [Mayeroff (1990)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_240){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_240 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} wrote: "I do not try to help the other grow in order to actualize myself, but by helping the other grow I do actualize myself" (p. 40). Singing the same song [Heppner (1989)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_164){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_164 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} said: "There is richness to the experience of relating on an intimate level with many people" (p. 74).

[]{#chapter2.xhtml_p17 .pagebreak aria-label="17" role="doc-pagebreak"}[Radeke and Mahoney (2000)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_313){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_313 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} describe some of the rewards in the high-touch field of psychotherapy (see [Table 2.1](#chapter2.xhtml_tbl2_1){#chapter2.xhtml_b2tbl2_1}). In comparing the experience of research psychologists and psychotherapists, the therapists were significantly higher on important dimensions.

+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------+

: [[Table 2.1]{.tablenum}](#chapter2.xhtml_b2tbl2_1){.backlink role="doc-backlink"} [Rewards of psychotherapy]{.table-title} {#tbl2_1 .table12a}

In their book, *Leaving It at the Office*, [Norcross and Guy (2018)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_274){.biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} cite the following as some of the rewards of practice: satisfaction of helping, freedom and independence, variety of experiences, intellectual stimulation, emotional growth, reinforcement for personality qualities, and life meaning. Some rewards are related to the "helper therapy principle," an idea first described by [Reissman in a classic 1965](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_316){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_316 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} article. The idea is that the giver in a human exchange gets a lot from giving. An example is the sponsor role in Alcoholics Anonymous (AA). In an article, Tom elaborated on Reissman\'s idea by suggesting four ways that giving is rewarding ([Skovholt, 1974](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_354){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_354 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}):

1.  *Identity development --* The idea here is that the giving role gives the practitioner a sense of identity. Also, the need for effectance motivation (the joy of being a cause) and competence motivation (the innate desire to be competent) is met through the practitioner\'s work. Last, a close connection with others reduces a sense of loneliness. In recent years, much professional literature in psychology has documented the importance of social connections for wellness. For example, [Rupert et al. (2009)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_338){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_338 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} found that when surveying psychologists, family support was an important ingredient for well-being, whereas conflict between work and family were associated with burnout.

2.  []{#chapter2.xhtml_p18 .pagebreak aria-label="18" role="doc-pagebreak"}*Social exchange theory --* Theories of social exchange attempt to explain the human rules used in resource exchange. [Foa (1971)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_121){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_121 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} developed a six-resource model: love, status, information, money, goods, and services. By giving one or more professional resources -- information and services -- the practitioner receives versions of love, status, and money. People, including practitioners, treasure receiving these resources.

3.  *Modeling --* The modeling literature is rich with examples of how we learn by observation. Examples are learning to teach by watching one\'s teacher and learning to parent by watching one\'s parent. This is a powerful human development method. Practitioners closely observe those they work with when attempting to make positive changes in an emotional, intellectual, spiritual, or physical area.

    Much of the interaction and observation occurs in private space, although some is public (i.e., the classroom). Like a cultural anthropologist in these encounters, the high-touch practitioner can closely observe human behavior and learn from it. Of course, this must be done in a way that is both ethical and in which the needs of the other are primary. Yet, these encounters do provide rich opportunities to learn via modeling. Often the learning is about deeper human themes, such as the impact of motivation on change, the ingredients of success, ways to encounter pain, and how friends and family affect goals. If done in an ethical way, this modelling can be instructive for the practitioner.

    Here is an example, Tom attended a ceremony for winners of teaching awards. Eight awards were given out. All eight of the award winners spoke passionately about how much they learned from their students. Ironic, in a way. These were distinguished professors. Aren't they supposed to be the givers of knowledge to the unenlightened? No, they spoke of how their students were their teachers and how grateful they were for what they had learned.

4.  *Direct reinforcement --* The practitioner\'s work can lead to direct social reinforcement, such as forms described by [Skinner (1953)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_353){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_353 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} of attention, approval, and affection. Certainly, getting reactions like these can help make the practitioner\'s work satisfying.
:::

::: section
## Gifts of Practice {#chapter2.xhtml_sec2_3 .head1}

Wisdom: An old-fashion quality that is often desirable. Wisdom develops from having experience with the complexities of living, like living for many decades and reflecting a lot on that experience. Perhaps wisdom develops faster for some described with the saying "that person is an old soul." Being a practitioner in the helping professions can in our view, accelerate the development of wisdom. If true, a gift of practice is the development of wisdom. [DuChene and Sundby (2022)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_98){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_98 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} cite the work []{#chapter2.xhtml_p19 .pagebreak aria-label="19" role="doc-pagebreak"}of [Jeste and LaFee (2020)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_182){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_182 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} on four elements of wisdom. Helping practitioners, through an integration of the professional and personal, naturally develop wisdom as defined by these Jeste and LaFee elements: **behavior** such as expressing empathy; **control** of one\'s own emotions ... think of the helping session; **reflection** ... think clinical supervision; **acceptance of uncertainty** ... think of listening in the first session; **making clear choice** ... think early diagnosis; **having a purpose/spiritual dimension** supporting others in pain. WOW, these developing wisdom elements are baked into the work of practitioners!

Another gift of practice is healing for the wounded healer. The wounded healer is a classic term described throughout history, discussed in the 20th century by Carl Jung as described in a wonderful book by Claire [Dunne (2015)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_100){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_100 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} titled *Carl Jung: Wounded Healer of the Soul*. It refers to the idea that the healer is motivated to enter helping professions because of their own wounds. Work in addictions is a common example of this. Victor [Frankl (1963)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_122){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_122 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} is an inspiring international example of finding meaning during horrible unjust suffering. He offers, through his book, a way for others to find meaning. Mother [Teresa (2007)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_398){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_398 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} too found great meaning through her work and dedication to serve the poorest of the poor. She increased the intensity of her efforts after sensing a calling in September, 1946 and starting the Missionaries of Charity. Her efforts were based on a deep religious calling from God. It seems that her work both helped her have less despair because of her great devotion to God and caused some depression because of her intense work with the poorest of the poor. These short sentences do not do justice to both great human beings, Victor Frankl and Mother Teresa.

Research on the well-being of 324 German psychotherapists reveals that the work can be healing. One component is the impact of clinical supervision where students are taught to share their work struggles; the imprecision of early practice always involves struggles. Clinical supervision teaches us to be reflective, open to learning and self-compassionate ([Rønnestad & Skovholt, 2013](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_334){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_334 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}). Self-compassion by itself has been shown to facilitate emotional health. [Neff (2011)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_263){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_263 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} has outlined three parts of self-compassion: self-kindness, common humanity and mindfulness. Self-compassion is like Carl Rogers' earlier ([1961](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_324){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_324 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}) concept of unconditional positive regard as described in *On Becoming a Person*. Years ago, I (Tom) heard Carl Rogers speak at a Counseling conference where he told the counselors in attendance to express unconditional positive regard toward themselves. Self-compassion/unconditional positive regard are important concepts for counselors who may be wounded themselves and perhaps perfectionists. Occasionally the wounder healer idea works so well the individual no longer needs the work to heal. This happened with one of Tom\'s PhD advisees. Some years after becoming a licensed psychologist and working with the population in therapy that reflected a painful part of her life, she told me she was dropping her license and []{#chapter2.xhtml_p20 .pagebreak aria-label="20" role="doc-pagebreak"}moving on in her life, feeling good about herself, no longer needing to do that work and happy to explore a new vocation.

Another great gift of practice is species immortality. This is a term that we use to describe the connection that we, as practitioners, have to the ongoing evolution of our species, *Homo sapiens.* Through relationship-intense work, practitioners are connected to the great human life chain that stretches from the far past into the far future. Like sharing one\'s DNA with others in a biological chain, practitioners, through their acts of empowering human growth, are connected in a positive way to the ongoing human story.

Connecting oneself to the growth and development of other people can provide enormous meaning, sometimes clearly felt, and sometimes less conscious, for the practitioner. When the search for meaning is elusive for so many in our 21st-century life, finding a source of meaning is a great gift to the relationship-intense practitioner. Conversely, meaning burnout, a concept explored in [Chapter 6](#chapter6.xhtml), can be very distressing for the practitioner because the gift of meaning is gone.

A master therapist quoted in [Norcross and Guy (2018)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_274){.biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} expresses this sentiment about the value of meaningful work:

> I have learned so much about life through the experiences of my clients. They have changed me, and I'm a better person for having been a part of their struggles and pain. I've lived several lifetimes and viewed life through the eyes of literally hundreds of people. This can't help but improve my own chances for a happy life. (p. 33)

Another gift of practice relates to how we grow at a deep and profound level through our work with our partners -- such as our clients, patients, students -- in the helping relationship. van Dernoot Lipsky describes her work in a hospital as a practitioner:

> Even at the most devastating moments of their lives, people somehow called up their highest selves. They were suffering on a level I could relate to, and yet despite their anguish, they didn't give up. I received an infusion of awe and hope with each and every shift ... I felt my old isolation melt. Because I had an opportunity to bear witness to others' pain while helping them to know they could be loved and taken care of as they suffered, I experienced a profound healing. My work at Harborview gave me a gift.
>
> [van Dernoot Lipsky & Burk (2009](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_410){#chapter2.xhtml_b2refbib_410 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}, pp. 118--119)

In summary, there can be great joys, rewards, and gifts for the practitioner. They can combine in unique forms at various times during a practitioner\'s life. They can vary in form and intensity across different practitioners and different caring career fields. Yet, although []{#chapter2.xhtml_p21 .pagebreak aria-label="21" role="doc-pagebreak"}differences exist, the positive qualities of the work -- the joys, rewards, and gifts -- can be very real and sustaining!
:::

# []{#chapter3.xhtml_p23 .pagebreak aria-label="23" role="doc-pagebreak"}[Chapter 3]{.chapnum}[The Cycle of Caring: Core of the Helping Professions]{.chaptitle} {#chapter3.xhtml_chapter3 .chaplabel}

Thomas M. Skovholt and Michelle Trotter-Mathison

DOI: [10.4324/9781003221388-4](https://doi.org/10.4324/9781003221388-4){aria-label="D.O.I. link to this document."}
:::

Pulling back the practitioner success curtain leads to a complicated view. One major stressor for practitioners is control of client outcome? Are we in charge of client outcomes. Yes and no. No and yes. The novice often feels the pressure of yes! The senior practitioner leans toward no. Here we present a way to greatly reduce the out of control yet feel responsible practitioner view. We have control of our part of the helping relationship.

The four phase Cycle of Caring is a process definition of practitioner success. The four phases are: Empathetic Attachment, Active Involvement, Felt Separation, and Renewal. All are key parts. In this process model doing the Cycle of Caring well is practitioner success! This is separate from the client\'s part of the helping relationship. A well know parallel here is the Serenity Prayer, control what you can.

The Cycle of Caring is a of paradoxical idea: embarrassingly simple yet complex. The goal with this idea is grand; to describe the essence of the work in the caring/relationship-intense professions! We all know about cycles as with the almost magical spin of own bike when a kid. The grand is capturing the essence of the work in one simple diagram!

[]{#chapter3.xhtml_p24 .pagebreak aria-label="24" role="doc-pagebreak"}Empathy may be the best one-word definition of the emotion needed by the practitioner to competently engage in the Cycle of Caring. Again, simple and grand. [Moudatsou et al. (2020)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_257){#chapter3.xhtml_b3refbib_257 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} recently described the importance of empathy while also finding that many practitioners find it difficult to be empathetic.

Psychotherapy researcher Jerome Frank produced evidence that many different helping methods are effective because of their common factors. The most important common factor was "an emotionally charged, confiding relationship with a helping person" ([Wampold & Weinberger, 2010](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_414){#chapter3.xhtml_b3refbib_414 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}, p. 34). Other counseling researchers reached the same conclusion: "some therapists consistently achieve better outcomes than others ... more effective therapists appear to be able to form working alliances across a range of clients ... and have a greater level of facilitation skills" ([Tracey et al., 2014](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_403){#chapter3.xhtml_b3refbib_403 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}, p. 225).

Compelling words from prominent researchers in the helping professions who have sifted through hundreds of research studies with this question: what is effective professional helping? A short answer: the helping relationship is key. Different counselling/therapy approaches seem to produce similar positive results. This equivalence of outcome is vexing for those who believe method is the deciding factor.

It boils down, as you can see from the research above, to the relationship-intense work of the working alliance.

::: section
## Caring: A Precondition for an Effective Helping Relationship {#chapter3.xhtml_sec3_1 .head1}

Much of our urgency in writing this book about the importance of being a resilient practitioner relates to the concept of caring. If we cannot feel -- think -- express caring for the Other, we are less useful in the helping professions. In [Chapter 6](#chapter6.xhtml), "Hemorrhaging of the Practitioner Self," we describe ways that the helper\'s attachment ability is drained by: burnout, compassion fatigue, vicarious traumatization, and ambiguous professional loss and uncertainty. Yikes, so many possibilities. The ability to care is fundamental to the Cycle of Caring as in "People who have had a great teacher almost always say, "That teacher saw something in me that I was unable to see in myself" ([Palmer, 2004](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_291){#chapter3.xhtml_b3refbib_291 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}, p. 82).

> It is better to know the patient who has the disease than it is to know the disease which the patient has.
>
> Hippocrates (460 BC--377 BC)

While I (Tom) was teaching in Singapore, a professor there, Vilma D'Rozario, and I asked people to describe in two words the teacher they *most liked* in their experience as students. Others were asked to describe their *best* teacher. Each person in this sample of 171 individuals gave two []{#chapter3.xhtml_p25 .pagebreak aria-label="25" role="doc-pagebreak"}words for a total of 342 words. The favorite word chosen did not describe how brilliant or well-educated the teacher was, the prestige of the teacher\'s university training, the methods of teacher education that the teacher learned or practiced, or the teacher\'s physical attractiveness. The most popular word described whether the person as a student felt cherished by the teacher in a personal way. The overwhelmingly popular word used to describe the most liked or best teacher was *caring.* Themes were created from the words in this study, with the strongest theme being *caring and understanding.* For this theme, the following words -- *caring*, *understanding*, *kind*, *patient*, *concerned*, *helpful*, and *loving* -- were stitched together to highlight the importance of the connection that the teacher makes with a student ([Skovholt & D'Rozario, 2000](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_363){#chapter3.xhtml_b3refbib_363 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"}).

In presentations since the study in Singapore, Tom and Michelle have both asked others in resiliency workshops and classes about their favorite teacher and have come up with similar results. For example, in September 2008, 14 doctoral students in professional psychology were asked to use three words to describe their favorite teacher. Their answers were consistent with other results, and again *caring* was the most popular word. Related words were *patient*, *supportive*, *kind*, *invested*, *engaged*, and *positive*. Another dimension was *humorous*. They also mentioned ideas like *knowledgeable*, *recognized my abilities*, and *high expectations*.

Right now, we ask that you think about your favorite teacher. What were her or his most amazing traits? In a fundamental way, your favorite teacher probably altered you. It may have been in your own view of your ability. Maybe your favorite teacher opened up a new field of study or way of understanding the world. Most people have some feeling of connection with their favorite teacher. Most describe the person as knowing about them personally and being concerned about them as a student. When there is a combination of your teacher being very knowledgeable in the content area, highly skilled in teaching the content, deeply committed to your welfare, and passionately caring for you as a person -- there is a favorite teacher! Without the personal caring, the other factors usually lose their powerful effect.

Reflecting on your favorite teacher: what were his or her most amazing traits? (Use the following oval to list your responses.)

Examining factors in student achievement, [Klem and Connell (2004)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_196){#chapter3.xhtml_b3refbib_196 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} found that teachers' support and caring were central to student success and participation: "Teacher support is important to student engagement in school as reported by students and teachers. Students who perceive teachers as creating a caring, well-structured learning environment in which expectations are high, clear, and fair are more likely to report engagement in school" (p. 270).

The capacity for self-discipline, an essential skill for student success, is often built on adult caring; this may help us understand why teacher caring is highly valued by students. [Mayeroff (1990)](#refbib.xhtml_refbib_240){#chapter3.xhtml_b3refbib_240 .biblioref role="doc-biblioref"} describes the benefits of caring this way: "Perhaps few things are more encouraging to another than to realize that his growth evokes admiration, a spontaneous delight or joy, in the one who cares for him" (p. 56). As additional evidence, let us mention how caring, defined as love, is the bedrock, central element in the parent-child bond. And think of popular songs you hear. No matter what song, singer, country, year, or decade, they often speak of one kind of caring -- romantic love -- usually found or broken.

Our premise is that caring is the essential quality that must be *maintained* in the relationship-intense career fields, where there are high levels of need and high levels of personal connection. Here, the inability to care is the most dangerous signal of burnout, ineffectiveness, and incompetence. The inability to care, therefore, must be strongly guarded against during one\'s career in these relationship-intense career fields.
